bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, March 15, 1929

div1.p: Carter updates Russell on her work and asks if Wakeman, a doctor with the International Health Division of the Rockefeller Foundation, died of yellow fever in West Africa.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, March 15, 1929
div1.opener:
Book
Misel.
Report (weekly)
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St. N.W.
Washington, D. C.
March 15, 1929.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
Miss Brown and I have put another satisfactory week's work,
and expect to get together again tonight.

A letter from Dr. Frost, received yesterday, said he hoped to
have some free time next week for us to work together, preparatory to
his resuming the final editing of Father's MS. This is indeed good
news! He cannot yet set the exact date for my going to Baltimore,
but if I do not write you next week it will be because I am over
there.

I was deeply distressed to read, in the daily papers, of
the death of Dr. Wakeman, on his way from West Africa with Dr.
Beeuwkes. Was it really yellow fever?
With heartfelt good wishes, I remain
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, (Signed) Laura A. Carter, Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division, The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York,
N. Y.
